questions.text: Potter facies and oligohydromnios are pathognomic of:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Potter facies and oligihydromnios occurs only in the presence of bilateral renal agenesis and due to complete absence of amniotic fluid production because of complete absence of both the kidneys. Unilateral renal agenesis will not lead to formation of such severe hydromnios as one of the kidneys is functioning absolutely fine and will give rise to amniotic fluid formation. Bilateral renal disease and unilateral cystic disease cannot lead to potter facies. Unilateral renal agenesis Complete absence of one kidney occurs in 1 in 500–1000 births and results from failure of connection between the metanephric blastema and the ipsilateral ureteric bud. This condition is an autosomal dominant trait with incomplete penetrance. Typically, there is an absent ipsilateral ureter and the ipsilateral hemi-trigone is missing in the bladder. The remaining kidney is usually hypertrophic but may also be dysplastic. In addition, the ipsilateral testis and vas deferens are usually absent and in some patients the adrenal gland on the affected side is missing as well. Females with the condition may have an absent ovary or Fallopian tube. Renal agenesis is different from renal aplasia where there is a small dysplastic kidney. Bilateral renal agenesis Bilateral renal agenesis is incompatible with life. It is associated with pulmonary hypoplasia and Potter’s facies due to oligohydramnios.

questions.text: Investigation of choice for documentation of obstructive nature of pelvicalyceal system dilatation: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The best method to look for obstructive nature of the pelvicalyceal system dilation is DTPA scan, as this is a dynamic scan, and tells us about the obstruction. As DTPA scan helps us know the dynamic component of the kidney function. Option A that is IVP is not the investigation of choice for looking at the hydronephosis as it is not a sensitive investigation for that. Whittaker test is a sensitive test for detecting PUJ obstruction but this is an invasive test and thus it is not the investigation of choice. Ultrasound is an investigation which is used to screen the patients of hydronephrosis but this is not the investigation of choice.

questions.text: Spider leg appearance in IVP is suggestive of: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Spider leg appearance is typical for renal cyst. Spider leg appearance is not seen in renal carcinoma, IOC for RCC is CECT. (In patients with contrast sensitivity MRI is done). Renal tuberculosis shows something which is known as putty kidney on X-Ray and when calcified it appears as cement kidney. Hydronephrosis in late stages shows blunting of pelvicalyceal system and thin rim of cortex on IVP In CRF we see small contracted kidneys So out of the above mentioned options spider leg appearance is typically seen with renal cysts only.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common renal cystic disease in infants ? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Polycystic kidney disease is the most common cystic disease of infancy. Most of the patients are affected in the intrauterine life and they die by the age of 4-6 weeks. Simple renal cysts most commonly affect elderly people. Unilateral renal dysplasia and calyceal cysts are not the most common cystic diseases of infancy.

questions.text: All of the following are features of adult polycystic kidney disease except: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Other name of adult polycystic disease is autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease. So option A is false . Option B is true as adult polycystic kidney disease has a tendency to present as a renal mass. Option C is also true as patients with polycystic kidney disease can present with hematuria. Option D is true as patients with adult polycystic kidney disease end up in renal failure by the age of 50-60 years .

questions.text: Polycystic kidney disease is associated with all of the following except (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Patients with adult polycystic kidney disease have a lot of extra intestinal manifestations : Option A is correct as cerebral berry aneurysm is one of the common extra renal manifestation of polycystic kidney disease . Option B is also correct as mitral valve prolapse is another complication. Option C is wrong as polycystic kidney disease do not predispose to Renal cell carcinoma. Option D is correct as hepatic cyst is the most common extra renal manifestation of polycystic kidney disease.

choices.text: Decompression of cyst leads to normal renal function

questions.text: Not true about polycystic kidney disease is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Earlier it was thaught that because of the pressure of the renal cyst over the renal parenchyma it does not develop well and leads to renal failure, so we used to perform Rovsing Operation which involved deroofing of the cysts. But over the period it was understood that the disease is caused by an intrinsic defect and not due to the pressure of the cyst on the renal parenchyma. So decompression of the cyst does not lead to normal renal function. Option A is correct as it is an autosomal dominant disease. Option B is correct as proteinuria < 2gm/ day is present. Option c is correct because over period of years polycystic kidney disease will be lead to CRF.

choices.text: Cysts are seen in liver spleen and pancreas

questions.text: In adult polycystic kidney, all are true except: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A is false as hypertension is the most common presenting feature in polycystic kidney disease. Option B is correct as hematuria is a common finding in patients of polycystic kidney disease. Option C is correct as in patients of polycystic kidney disease we see a lot of extra renal manifestations and cysts in liver spleen and pancreas are very common finding. Option D is correct as polycystic kidney disease has an autosomal dominant transmission.

questions.text: True of autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease I and II respectively: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) hromosome number for autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease I and II is 16 and 4 respectively. Chromosome number for autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease is 6.

questions.text: Polycystic kidney may be associated with cyst in all the sites except: (AIIMS May 2014)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Heart Liver is the most common extra renal organ where cysts are seen. Other organs where cysts are seen are Pancreas , spleen , brain , lungs .

questions.text: Treatment of choice in polycystic kidney is: (AIIMS Nov 2015)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A is wrong as Rovsing Operation was done which involved deroofing of the cysts But over the period it was understood that the disease is caused by an intrinsic defect and not due to the pressure of the cyst on the renal parenchyma. So decompression of the cyst does not lead to normal renal function. Option B is wrong as autosomal polycystic disease is a B/L condition we can not do B/L Nephrectomy as a treatment option for the patient. Option c is wrong. Although we do use dialysis as a treatment option for symptomatic relief and till kidney is arranged it is not the treatment of choice as patient will have to subjected to long term dialysis and will have a lot of complications. Option D that is kidney transplantation is the treatment of choice for polycystic kidney disease patients.

questions.text: "Spider leg" deformity in excretory urogram occurs in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) In patients of polycystic kidney disease we see spider leg appearance on IVP. In a patient of hydronephrosis on IVP we see blunting of calyces. In ureterocele we see adder head appearance on IVP We can not visualise the kidney on IVP if patient has renal agenesis.

questions.text: Triad of renal colic, swelling in loin which reduces on passing urine is called: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Intermittent ureteropelvic junction obstruction, often associated with an aberrant vessel to the lower pole of the kidney, may cause a distinct clinical syndrome of episodic colicy abdominal pain, associated with swelling in the loin followed by passage of large amount of urine along with relieve in the pain of the patient. The constellation of the above symptoms is referred to as Dietel’s Crisis. Kocher’s triad is also called terrible triad is associated with elbow dislocation, coronoid fracture and radial head fracture. Saint’s triad is associated with gall stones and comprises of gall stones, diverticulosis and hiatus hernia. Charcot’s triad is associated with acute cholecystitis and comprises of intermittent pain, intermittent fever and jaundice.

questions.text: Sheela, a middle aged diabetic female presented with flank pain and fever. On U/S the kidney was irregular and showed fat density lesion with calculi. The diagnosis is most probably: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Xanthogranulomatous pyelonephritis is caused by infection occurring in a chronically obstructive kidney and most common cause of obstruction is stone. Because of this there occurs infection with proteus and it leads to xanthogranulomatous pyelonephritis. On CT scan it shows fat density and is a DD of Clear cell carcinoma of kidney. TB kidney does not presents like this, in this you see hydronephrosis in early stage and putty and cement kidney in later stages. Renal abscess presents as pus filled in the renal parenchyma.

questions.text: Renal cell carcinoma histopathologically showing 'perinuclear halo' and "Plant like" structure in malignant cells is seen in: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Chromophobe RCC presents as a large cells with clear cytoplasm with thick cell membrane. The have a nucleus with fine reticular appearance and a perinuclear halo. These findings are similar to what we get in plant cells so renal cell carcinoma which appears as plant cell is chromophobe type. Option A is wrong as clear cell carcinoma only has a clear cell on histopathology because of washing of the intracellular content while processing the slide. Papillary and collecting duct carcinomas don’t look like plant cells.

questions.text: The most common histological variant of renal cell carcinoma is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) clear cell carcinoma is the most common histologic variety of renal cell carcinoma. Option C is papillary cell carcinoma and this is the most common type of RCC in patients who have developed cystic disease of kidney due to chronic dialysis.

questions.text: Bilateral renal cell carcinoma is seen in: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Von hipple lindau syndrome is mutation occurring in VHL gene on chromosome 3p. It is associated with clear cell carcinoma and it leads to the formation of bilateral RCC. Eagle barret syndrome is not associated with formation of RCC. Beckwith Weidman syndrome is associated with wilms tumour and not RCC. Bilateral angiomyolipoma is a feature of tuberous sclerosis.

questions.text: Most common site of origin of RCC: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Most common site of origin of RCC is PCT. Although RCC can also arise from other parts of a nephron like DCT, collecting duct and loop of henle.

questions.text: Not correct regarding renal cell carcinoma: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option C is wrong as RCC is more common in males as compared to females. Option A is correct as RCC of left side have a tendancy to grow into renal vein and obstruct the left side testicular vein and lead to formation of left sided varicocele. Option B is correct as RCC is a tumour which has a propensity to grow in the renal vein as a tumour thrombus. Option D is correct as RCC can arise from PCT, infact PCT is the most common site of the nephron from which RCC arises.

questions.text: Most common site for secondary metastasis in a case of hypernephroma: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Most common site of metastasis in case of RCC is lungs and we get typical cannon ball metastasis in lungs in a patient of RCC who has developed metastasis.

choices.text: Associated with anemia and raised ESR
Invasion of renal vein is contraindication for surgery

questions.text: Regarding RCC all are true except: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) RCC has a predisposition to grow in renal vein as a tumour thrombus and spread but involvenment of renal vein or IVC is not a contraindication for surgery of RCC. Option A is correct as renal lump, pain abdomen and hematuria forms a triad of RCC but this triad is present only in 15 % of patients. Out of these three the most common feature is hematuria. Option B is correct RCC has a tendency to develop many paraneoplastic syndromes and anaemia and raised ESR are few among these.

questions.text: Commonest manifestation of Grawitz's tumor in male:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Grawitz’s tumour is another name for RCC and most common presentation of this tumour is hematuria. Secondary deposits, pathological fractures and rapidly developing varicocele are other manifestations but the most common one is hematuria.

choices.text: Chest X-ray should be done to rule out pulmonary metastasis

questions.text: A patient presented with renal cell carcinoma invading IVC and renal vein. False statement is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option B is wrong as IVC involvement does not indicate inoperability in RCC. Option A is correct as diagnosis of renal malignancy is mostly radiological as we do not insist on the pathological tissue diagnosis before the operation. Option C is correct as pre operative radiotherapy is not essential and RCC is not responsive to radio and chemotherapy. Option D is correct as we need to do a chest X-ray to rule out pulmonary metastasis as pulmonary metastasis is visible as cannon ball mets in lungs.

questions.text: Most important prognostic indicator for renal cell carcinoma: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Most important prognostic indicator for renal cell carcinoma is pathological stage. Most important prognostic indicator for wilm’s tumor is histological type.

choices.text: Arise from cortex usually from pre existing adenoma
May present with rapidly developing varicocele

questions.text: False regarding hypernephroma is: (AIIMS Nov 2014)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A is the answer as renal tumors are radio and chemo resistant. Option B is correct as it arises mostly from the cortex from PCT and arises from pre existing adenoma. Option C is correct as RCC tends to grow along the veins as a tumor thrombus it can obstruct the left testicular vein which drains into the left renal vein and can present as an irreducible varicocele of left side. Option D is correct as most of RCC are histologically adenocarcinoma

questions.text: Ideal approach for renal malignancy is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) When you operate for a benign renal condition like a kidney stone, we prefer a subcostal incision as the kidney is a retroperitoneal structure and we tend to approach the kidney via a retroperitoneal route. But when we have to operate for renal malignancy we prefer a midline transperitoneal route as it helps us to gain a good access to the kidney and access other organs for any spread of the malignancy.

questions.text: Renal collar to prevent spread of malignancy from kidney is put around: (PGI May 2015)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) renal cell carcinoma tends to spread along the renal vein as a tumour thrombus. This is the reason while performing a radical nephrectomy we have to apply a renal collar around the renal vein to prevent the spread of the tumour and then ligate the renal artery first to reduce the blood entering the kidney so that the size of the kidney is reduced. Option A and B is false as while operating on kidney we stay away from aorta and IVC which is in best interest of the patient. Option D would have been the answer if the question would have asked which structure will you ligate first.

choices.text: All three type can be easily detected on exfoliative cytology

questions.text: A patient with a suspected renal tumor/mass is diagnosed by exfoliative urinary cytology. Which of the following histological types is most Iikely to be diagnosed on urinary exfoliative cytology? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Exfoliative cytology is not a very good test to make the diagnosis of of renal and urinary bladder tumors because of its poor sensitivity. Transitional cell carcinoma has cells which are poorly bound to each other, this characteristic is known as poor cohesiveness of the cells. Because of poor cohesiveness, these cells get detached from one other and are shed in urine and diagnosis of transitional cell carcinoma is possible. The major disadvantage is it cannot distinguish whether the transitional cell carcinoma is arising from urinary bladder or kidney or renal pelvis or ureter. Adenocarcinoma can not be diagnosed on exfoliative cytology.

questions.text: The commonest systemic abnormality associated with renal cell carcinoma is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) There are many paraneoplastic syndromes associated with renal cell carcinoma. Raised ESR is the most common among these. Hypertension and polycythemia are the other paraneoplastic syndromes associated with renal cell carcinoma. Pyrexia is a paraneoplastic syndrome associated with renal cell carcinoma.

choices.text: Radical nephrectomy with immediate renal transplantation

questions.text: A 40 years old patient with a single kidney presents with a solitary exophytic mass of 4 cm localized at-its lower pole. Which amongst the following is the best recommended management option? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) As the patient has a single kidney with a mass in it we have to go for partial nephrectomy so that the tumor is taken care of and patient retains the kidney function as well. If we go for radical nephrectomy for a patient with solitary kidney he will be left with no kidney at all and this will be a very serious situation and will need either a new kidney in the form of renal transplant which is not possible as patient had cancer and if he is put on dialysis, patient will have to bear lot of complications which come along with dialysis. So best option for this is partial nephrectomy.

questions.text: Commonest presentation of Wilm’s tumour is (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) MC presenting feature of wilm’s tumour is asymptomatic abdominal mass or swelling. Characterized by triad seen in wilms tumour is abdominal mass, fever and microscopic hematuria.

choices.text: Age less than 1 year at presentation

questions.text: The most important determinant of prognosis in wilm’s tumor is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Most important prognostic factor of wilms tumour is Histology of the tumour. On HPE , there will be epithelial and blastemal component. Higher the blastemal component poorer the prognosis.

questions.text: The ideal timing of radiotherapy for Wilms tumour after surgery is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) In unfavorable histology, Radiation therapy should be started within 10 days after nephrectomy and Chemotherapy should be started 5 days after surgery. Wilm's tumor will be both radiosensitive and chemosensitive while RCC are radioresistant and chemoresistant.

questions.text: Commonest site of metastasis of Wilms tumour is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Most common site of metastasis in renal tumours like RCC and Wilms tumour is Lungs. Wilms tumour being metastasised to bone, liver and brain is rare.

questions.text: Which of the following is the postchemotherapy based staging system in Wilms tumor? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Post chemotherapy based staging in wilm’s tumour is developed by International society of Pediatric Oncology (SIOP) Pre chemotherapy based staging in wilm’s tumour is developed by National wilm’s tumour staging system (NWTSG)

questions.text: All are associated with Wilms tumour except: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Wilms tumour is associated with WAGR syndrome which stands for Wilms tumour, Aniridia, Genitourinary malformation and mental retardation. Wilms tumour is also associated with Beckwith-Wiedmann Syndrome. It consists of enlargement of body organs, hemi hypertrophy, renal medullary cysts and abnormal large cells in adrenal cortex, macroglossia, omphalocele, hepatoblastoma. Associated with WT-2 gene deletion located on chromosome 11p 15.5. Wilm's tumor is also associated with Deny's Drash syndrome .it consists of Intersex features and Mental retardation.

questions.text: Which of the following is the treatment of choice for stage I Wilm’s tumor? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The treatment of choice for stage I Wilm’s tumor is transperitoneal radical nephrectomy (radical nephroureterectomy) followed by chemotherapy with or without radiotherapy depending upon tumor histology.

questions.text: Wilm's tumor chromosome is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The gene which is mutated in wilms tumour is WT gene and it is located on chromosome 11p13. 13q14 is the gene responsible for retinoblastoma.
